item.title: Estimating lim values tables
item.description: Tables can be a powerful tool to approximate a limit, but they need to be used wisely. Learn how to create tables in order to find a good approximation of a limit, and learn how to approximate a limit given a table of values

item.title: Estimating limit values from graphs
item.description: Estimating Limit values from graphs There’s a difference between the value a function is approaching – what we call the limit– and the value of the function itself

item.title: Limit Properties
item.description: lim f(x) = L x -> c lim g(x) = M x -> c lim(f(x) + g(x)) = L + M Sum property of limits x -> c

item.title: Limits
item.description: Strategy ![[images/Pasted image 20230803121917.png]] Notation ![[images/Pasted image 20230718191020.png]] Rules lim k = k, for any constant a -> k lim x = a x -> a lim[f(x) $\pm$ g(x)] = lim f(x) $\pm$ lim g(x) x -> a x -> a x -> a lim[cf(x)] = c [limf(x)], for any constant c x -> a x -> a lim[f(x)g(x)] = [lim f(x)][lim g(x)] x -> a x -> a x -> a lim $\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}$ = $\frac{lim f(x)}{lim g(x)}$ provided that lim g(x) $\neq$ 0 x -> a x -> a lim[f(x)]$^n$ = [lim f(x)]$^n$, for any number n x -> a x -> a Methods [[Direct Substitution Limit]] [[Factoring Method Limit]] [[Multiplying by the Conjugate]] [[Change of Variable Method]] Notation and meaning x -> 1$^+$ = Approaching 1 from the right x -> 1$^-$ = Approaching 1 from the left lim = limit of f(x), as approaches c equals L

item.title: Limits by direct substitution
item.description: Directly substitute what you are approaching as the value of x Requirement for this method You can check if you can calculate the limit using the direct substitution method by doing this

item.title: Limits by Factoring
item.description: Prerequisite: [[Indeterminate Form]] is returned after using [[Limits by direct substitution]] method How to solve You can factor! f(x) = $\Huge{\frac{x^2 + x - 6}{x - 2}}$

item.title: Limits by rationalizing
item.description: Example g(x) = $\Huge{\frac{x+1}{\sqrt{x+5}-2}}$ To rationalize this you would multiply the numerator and denominator by $\sqrt{x + 5}$ + 2

item.title: Limits for composite functions (no external limit)
item.description: Always approach the limit from the left and right handed Problem Example equation: g(h(x)) lim x -> 1

item.title: Limits for composite functions (no internal limit)
item.description: Problem Example equation: g(h(x)) lim x -> -1 When the h(x) for the lim of x -> -1 doesn’t exist people wonder what to do but there’s a way to solve these kind of problems

item.title: Limits Intro
item.description: What is limit? Limit describes how a function behaves near a point instead of at that point. This is simple yet powerful idea that is the basis of all of calculus

item.title: Limits of Combined Functions
item.description: lim[f(x) * h(x)] x -> 0 To solve this problem you would first have to find the limit of f(x) when it approaches 0 and then find the limit of h(x) when it approaches 0 then multiply them both

item.title: Limits of combined functions (piecewise)
item.description: When using [[Limit properties]] to solve limit equations but it seems like the limit may NOT exist due to the left and right limits not being the same use this method

item.title: Limits of piecewise functions
item.description: Limits of piecewise functions can differ from the direction we’re approaching them from For example f(x) = $\Huge{{}$ $\frac{x + 2}{x - 1}$ for 0 < x $\leq$ 4 $\sqrt{x}$ for x > 4

item.title: Limits of trigonometric functions
item.description: Use [[Trigonometry Identities]] to replace with equations we are familiar with, after substitute the limit in and solve Identities applied with limits lim sin(x) = sin(a) x -> a

item.title: Limits using Trig Identities
item.description: Refer to [[Trigonometry Identities]] to solve these problems Example (Pythagorean Identity) lim $\Huge{\frac{1 - cos \theta}{2 sin^2 \theta}}$ = $\Huge{\frac{1 - cos\theta}{2 (1-cos^2\theta)}}$ = $\Huge{\frac{1-cos\theta}{2(1+cos\theta)(1-cos\theta)}}$ = $\Huge{\frac{1}{2+2cos\theta}}$ , $\theta$ $\neq$ 0 $\theta$ -> 0

item.title: Theorem for limits
item.description: lim f(g(x)) = f(lim g(x)) x -> a x -> a The statement listed above can only be true if 2 conditions are sufficed
